Carouge is a municipality in the Canton: Carouge is first mentioned in the Early Middle Ages as Quadruvium and Quatruvio.  In 1248 it was mentioned as Carrogium  while in the 14th Century it was known as Quarrouiz or Quarroggi.  In 1445 it was mentioned as Quaroggio.  The current city was built  by Victor Amadeus III of Sardinia
King of Sardinia and Duke of Savoy
column3: starting in 1760–70. It obtained the status of city in 1786.Carouge was taken by revolutionary France in 1792
column4: apparently with considerable local support. During the Napoleonic wars
column5: in 1814 Carouge was reincorporated into the Kingdom of Sardinia following a brief occupation by Austria. The Treaty of Turin (1816) transferred Carouge to the Canton of Geneva and therefore became part of the Swiss Confederation.

Carouge is a municipality in the Canton: The Archives of Carouge is listed as a Swiss heritage site of national significance.  The entire village of Carouge is listed in the Inventory of Swiss Heritage Sites.
